text:
I seem to have the same issue with backtest_multi.py example that few others have mentioned, in that I get a "UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte......"  error, even though the example uses smart_open.
Has anyone pinned down a solution to this? It works fine if I'm doing a standard (not 'multi') backtest.

text:
Are you running from .zip files? If so I think that this edit to the above file might solve the problem:
```with patch("builtins.open", smart_open.open):
    framework.add_strategy(strategy)
    framework.run()```

elements.text: Are you running from .zip files? If so I think that this edit to the above file might solve the problem:

with patch("builtins.open", smart_open.open):
    framework.add_strategy(strategy)
    framework.run()

text: IIRK smart_open can't actually handle zip files. This is because unlike .gz and .bz2 files, .zips are an archive with the directory structure needed to support many files, so opening one would just expose more files, rather than the data in a compressed file.

elements.text: IIRK smart_open can't actually handle zip files. This is because unlike .gz and .bz2 files, .zips are an archive with the directory structure needed to support many files, so opening one would just expose more files, rather than the data in a compressed file.

text: Apologies - I was referring to .gz files, not .zip. The code above is how I run .gz files, but my knowledge is (clearly) very limited so to be honest I have no idea why it works

elements.text: Apologies - I was referring to .gz files, not .zip. The code above is how I run .gz files, but my knowledge is (clearly) very limited so to be honest I have no idea why it works

text: Easy to get confused about this. The market recorder used to store the data in zip archives, but fairly recently <@U4H19D1D2> converted it to save the data in gzips instead - a significant improvement in usability.

elements.text: Easy to get confused about this. The market recorder used to store the data in zip archives, but fairly recently
converted it to save the data in gzips instead - a significant improvement in usability.

text: On the original question from <@U02J5GMLJF6>, I have had this problem too. On one occasion it proved to be because my gzip files were double gzipped, i.e. unzip them and the result was still a gzip. But that's not the only reason this occurs. I'm still looking for a solution myself or some of the files affected by this issue. Irritatingly, if I download a new version from S3, it sometimes works, once, then starts failing again, making me wonder whether the files are somehow not being closed properly at the end of the streaming.

elements.text: On the original question from

, I have had this problem too. On one occasion it proved to be because my gzip files were double gzipped, i.e. unzip them and the result was still a gzip. But that's not the only reason this occurs. I'm still looking for a solution myself or some of the files affected by this issue. Irritatingly, if I download a new version from S3, it sometimes works, once, then starts failing again, making me wonder whether the files are somehow not being closed properly at the end of the streaming.

text: <@U9JHLMZB4> has nailed this. I had the same problem when using the old marketrecorder. The zip files are archives that contain the file. I ended up running a python script to unzip the files and then re-save as .gz format. There's probably a nicer way of doing it though...

elements.text: has nailed this. I had the same problem when using the old marketrecorder. The zip files are archives that contain the file. I ended up running a python script to unzip the files and then re-save as .gz format. There's probably a nicer way of doing it though...

text: Would also suggest updating your marketrecorder to the latest version as that saves the data in gzip format.

elements.text: Would also suggest updating your marketrecorder to the latest version as that saves the data in gzip format.

text: <@U01RPPFV7L3> has joined the channel

Hi guys & gals, not sure if this is the right channel for that. 

I'm running Randwick Group, a sports & racing trading company in Sydney. Founders come from hedge fund and prop FX trading background. We treat sports trading as just another asset class & run the business just like any other high quality hedge fund. 
We currently have 4 traders across racing, basketball and esports. 
Weâ€™ve raised additional capital from our investors and are now looking to hire more traders (ideally trading soccer, cricket, UK racing and NFL) to allocate capital to. 

We don't need you to work on this full time, and we're happy for you to trade on personal account as well. We offer market leading profit share of your trading. We respect your IP and don't require you to share your secret sauce. We provide you with a funded account and you trade any way you like (within risk parameters!) 

What we need is a verifiable track record (ideally on BetFair) of deploying money - so no backrests please. DM for a job description or if you have any questions. 
<http://www.RandwickGroup.com|www.RandwickGroup.com>

text:
Hmmmm, odd. I seem to recall having issues with the bz2 files from betfair. Have you tried converting a handful of files to gzip or even just decompress them to plain text? The smart_open docs suggest that there's an alternative install for S3, etc, but I've never used it:
`pip install smart_open[all]`
That supposedly adds lots of dependencies, so may include the bz2 library.
